item.title: Adapt your beauty routine to the changing weather conditions
item.description: Mintel Beauty & Personal Care (BPC) has recognized a new global beauty trend: seasonality. This trend reflects how different weather conditions influence beauty routines. Source: Mintel website. According to Mintel BPC, product launches related to this trend significantly increased from 9.8% in 2011 to 11.1% in 2014. This is particularly noticeable in facial skincare, where seasonal product launches grew from a mere 0.5% in 2009 to 1.2% in 2014. Jane Henderson, Global President of Mintelâ€™s Beauty and Personal Care Division, notes a growing consumer awareness of how environmental changes impact their skin and hair.

item.title: Asians struggle with their comfort levels when it comes to using air conditioning
item.description: A Hong Kong-based startup, Ambi Labs, has initiated a crowdsourcing campaign for their latest product, Ambi Climate. This innovative device is designed to optimize air conditioning systems based on two years of user feedback gathered from ten Asian markets. Source: Ambi Labs. Ambi Labs conducted extensive online surveys across ten major Asian markets, engaging with over 4,000 participants. The findings revealed that the most significant challenge with air conditioners lies in maintaining a comfortable room temperature.

item.title: The KPMG index assesses the capacity of 140 countries to adapt to change
item.description: According to the 2019 KPMG Change Readiness Index (CRI), countries in the Asia Pacific region are generally showing improvement in their approaches to climate change. Singapore’s ranking rose two spots to number 2, while Taiwan jumped 18 places. Published twice a year, the CRI is now in its fourth year. It ranks 140 countries* based on their preparedness for and response to major change events. This edition focuses on the capabilities countries need to effectively combat climate change and minimize related risks.

item.title: Eight multilateral development banks (MDBs) working together to speed up efforts to reduce transportation emissions
item.description: Eight major development banks have come together to address the significant impact of transportation on climate change. These institutions acknowledge that the transportation sector, responsible for a considerable portion of global energy consumption and emissions, needs more action to minimize its environmental footprint and enhance its resilience to climate change. The African Development Bank, Asian Development Bank (ADB), CAF-Development Bank of Latin America, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, European Investment Bank, Inter-American Development Bank, Islamic Development Bank (ISDB), and the World Bank (WB) have pledged to expedite their efforts in several key areas.

item.title: In 2015, Bhutan made significant improvements to its business climate
item.description: Bhutan has significantly improved its business environment, earning a global ranking of 71st out of 189 countries in the World Bank Group’s annual ease of doing business assessment. This achievement places Bhutan at the top spot within the South Asia Region. The Doing Business 2016: Measuring Regulatory Quality and Efficiency report highlights two key reforms implemented by Bhutan. First, obtaining an electricity connection is now faster, taking only 61 days compared to 93 days five years ago.
